description: See the archaeological excavations and Tudor foundations at Scadbury Moated Manor - which still has its moat around it.

events.name: Drop in
events.notes: Site open Saturday 14th and Sunday 15th September. 14.00-17.00 (Last entry 16.30).

events.name: Drop in
events.notes: Site open Saturday 14th and Sunday 15th September 14.00-17.00 (last entry 16.30).

factsheet.heading: History
paragraphs: The first family to settle at the moated site was the de Scathebury family around 1200AD. In 1424 Thomas Walsingham bought the estate. The Walsingham family had connections with the royal court; the brick manor house and farm buildings date from their time. Queen Elizabeth I visited Scadbury in 1597. The family sold Scadbury Manor to Sir Richard Bettenson in 1660. The estate was later purchased by John Selwyn and settled upon his son-in-law Thomas Townshend. The moated manor house was pulled down in 1738 but in the 20th century the family lived in a country house nearby. The Home Guard had a base at Scadbury during World War II.  In 1983 the family sold the estate to Bromley Council.

factsheet.heading: What you can see on a visit
paragraphs:
You will see the original moat still filled with water, go on to the island to see the foundations of the brick Walsingham house including the site of the kitchen and hall, and then return from 
the island and pass the farm buildings to see the exterior of the bunker used as an air-raid shelter and Home Guard centre in World War II. You will also see our current excavation at the site.

location.address: Scadbury Moated Manor, Perry Street, Chislehurst, BR7 6LN
travel_info: Additional travel info: B14 & R11 bus from St Mary Cray Station to Breakspeares Drive, footpath next to 14 St Pauls Wood Hill, follow signs to site, 10 minute walk.

name: Scadbury Moated Manor
